Taking a look at the standings in the AFC, we see the Chiefs at the top of the conference with the one seed locked up. Every division is wrapped up except the AFC North which will come down to who comes out on top between the Ravens and Steelers. The Chargers and Broncos came into the week tied at 9-6 occupying two of the three Wild Card spots. If both of those teams win, they are in. The Bengals need to win out, see the Broncos lose out and see the Colts and Dolphins lose or tie one of their next two. The Broncos have the Bengals today and the Chiefs next week, but with the Chiefs having the one seed, they may not come out in full force on the final week of the season. First things first. Both of these teams need a win today before worrying about the future. The Broncos were in desperate need of a QB after having a carrousel of QBs come and go in the Mile High City. With the 8th pick in the draft, Sean Payton and the Broncos took Bo Nix out of the University of Oregon, and Payton had his man. He groomed him into being an NFL QB and it didn’t take too long. He threw four picks and zero TDs in the first three games of the season but after that he would throw 13 TDs and just 2 picks in the next nine games. He has 3,235 yards, 22 TDs and 11 INTs on the year, and is contention for Rookie of the Year but more importantly, he has this team primed for a playoff appearance. All eyes will be on Joe Burrow today in this playoff type game from Cincy. Despite the Bengals record, he has been putting up incredible numbers worthy of MVP consideration. He leads the NFL in passing yards and passing TDs with 4,229 yards and 39 TDs with just 8 INTs, but that has only translated in seven wins because the defense has been horrendous for the Bengals this year. Burrow knows if they are going to keep their playoff chances alive, he is going to need to keep playing like an MVP. As always, there was a lot of hype surrounding this Bengals team coming into the season. They missed the playoffs last year after Burrow missed the second half of the season, but he was back this season and Joe Burrow and Ja’Marr Chase will always put you in contention. They lost their first three and four of their first five, and would struggle to string wins together. Burrow reassured that the Bengals would bounce back and if they got to 10 wins, that should get them to the postseason. Their three game losing streak that finished with a shootout against the Chargers guaranteed they weren’t going to get to 10 wins, that’s when the Bengals turned on. They have won three straight against the Cowboys, Titans and Browns, and need to keep winning to have any chance. Not much was expected of the Broncos coming into the season. They had been terrible over the last few seasons and brought in a rookie QB to get this team out of the gutter. They lost their first two games as Bo Nix dinked and dunked his way down the field, but he would turn it on and lead the Broncos to five wins over the next six games. A losing skid against the Ravens and Chiefs would bring them back to earth, but they would rattle off another four wins before their loss last week in LA. The Broncos haven’t been to the playoffs since 2015, but finally they have a QB, who is a rookie, and a defense that is the foundation of this team that is a win away from the playoffs. The Bengals rattled off their third straight win to stay alive in the playoff race and as always they were relying on their MVP caliber QB Joe Burrow to lead them there. The defense came up with a couple big plays throughout the day including their forced fumble at the 1 yard line and Burrow would lead his team on a 99 yard drive to take the lead and keep the lead for the rest of the day. Another TD pass and field goal right before the half put the Bengals up 14-0 and the defense would come up with two second half picks to hold off DTR and the Browns. Burrow would throw his third of the day on a 32 yard bomb to Ja’marr Chase to put the icing on the cake. Last Thursday it looked like the Broncos were going to cruise to a Wild Card birth as they ran all over the Chargers in the first half. A running back by committee in the first half as the Broncos went up 21-10 in the first half, but then the offense shut down. The first Fair Catch kick in a half century was awarded to the Chargers right before half and that seemed to turn the tides in LA. They stopped running the ball, and the offense slowed to a halt as the Chargers lit up the scoreboard scoring TDs on three of their four second half possessions to win the gam 34-27 and delay the Broncos playoff birth for at least another week. Hello everyone and welcome to Cincinnati where the Bengals somehow, someway still have a chance at a playoff spot after a three game winning streak. It was a rough start to the season despite an MVP type season from Joe Burrow, and they come into today’s game knowing they need to win out and get a lot of help around the league. The Broncos had a chance to clinch their playoff spot last week but were beaten in a division match up so now they have to go on the road against a red hot Bengals team in their stadium. There is a playoff spot on the line today from Cincinnati. Two teams with playoff aspirations come into the penultimate week of the season knowing the postseason is a possibility but today’s game is a must win. One team is so close they can taste it, while the other will need a win today and a near miracle in Week 18. It’s the Denver Broncos taking on the Cincinnati Bengals from Paycor Stadium and AS English will be with you all day providing stats, scores and highlights of today’s game packed with playoff implications.

UConn football.title: UConn Huskies football - Wikipedia
UConn football.content: The UConn Huskies football team is a college football team that represents the University of Connecticut in the sport of American football. The team competes in NCAA Division I FBS as an independent. Connecticut first fielded a team in 1896, and participated in Division I-AA until 1999. The Huskies began their two-year Division I-A transition period in 2000, and became a full-fledged Division I-A team in 2002. From 2000 to 2003, the team played as an independent. The school's football team then joined the conference of its other sport teams, the Big East (later named the American Athletic Conference (AAC) in 2013), taking effect in 2004, through 2019. In 2019, the UConn football team left the American to again play as an independent, as the school's current primary conference, the current Big East, does not sponsor the sport. The Huskies are currently coached by Jim Mora.[2] The University of Connecticut began playing football in 1896 when the school was known as Storrs Agricultural College, and the team was known as the "Aggies." It teamed up with Massachusetts Agricultural College and the Rhode Island College of Agriculture and the Mechanic Arts to form the Athletic League of New England State Colleges for the purpose of scheduling football matchups between the schools. The first year was spent playing against local high schools and YMCA clubs. The following year provided their first competition against future rivals Rhode Island, an opponent that would be played over 100 times, and Massachusetts. Other early rivals included the Ivy League and the "Little Ivies", particularly Yale University starting in 1948, who have played the Huskies for 50 years. Tragedy struck the team on September 27, 1919, when Gardner Dow died from injuries related to a flying tackle that he delivered in a game against New Hampshire.[3][4] The college would honor Dow by naming the athletic fields after him. These fields would become the home for most of the school's athletic teams for the next three decades. In 1924, the Aggies celebrated their first undefeated season when they finished with six wins, no losses and two ties. The defense was the strength of the team, as they allowed a meager thirteen points to be scored against them over the entire season, including a total of three points over the final seven games.[5] The team was proclaimed by The New York Times to be among the best in the country, and was led by the school's first All-America candidate in captain, Martin "Red" O'Neill.[6] The UConn Club memorializes O'Neill with a yearly award given to a former student-athlete who has had a successful professional career. Red O'Neill went on to become one of Connecticut's first players to play in the NFL. He played for the Hartford Blues in 1926, their only year in the NFL.[7] Another player is Art "Pop" Williams, winning a championship with the Providence Steam Roller in 1928 and also has the record for the most rushing career touchdowns in Providence's franchise history.[8] The Steam Roller are New England's first NFL champion. The renamed Huskies went on to become long-time members of the Yankee Conference, winning 15 conference championships. In 2012, Bill Belichick stated in an interview on WEEI that in 1983 he applied for the Huskies' head coaching position but was eventually turned down in favor of an internal hire, Tom Jackson. Connecticut hired Lew Perkins as its athletic director in 1990. One of Perkins' first projects was to gather facts for a possible upgrade of the football program to Division I-A.[9] Perkins feared that if the university did not upgrade the football program, that it ran the risk of falling behind other institutions that fielded both football and basketball teams at the highest level. However, UConn was in the middle of a budget deficit and many faculty feared that an upgrade of the football program would result in a loosening of academic standards.[9] Randy Edsall was named the 27th head football coach at the University of Connecticut on December 21, 1998, and led the Huskies from Division I-AA into Division I-A. UConn officially began the upgrade process in January 1999 by applying to join the Big East football conference.[10] They would receive a special waiver from the NCAA in order to play in Memorial Stadium while Rentschler Field was under construction.[11] UConn would become the first school to ever move from the FCS to the Bowl Championship Series as a member of the Big East after three years as an independent. The Huskies would spend the 2000 and 2001 as a transitional Division I-A program as they built their scholarship base to the maximum of 85. They recorded their first win over a Division I-A opponent on September 18, 1999, when they defeated Buffalo, 23-0. They would finish the 1999 season with a final record of 4-7, and the following 2000 season at 3-8. [12] The 2001 season brought their first win over a BCS rival with a victory over Rutgers on September 29, by a score of 20–19. The growing pains continued, as they finished the season at 2–9. The breakthrough came during the Huskies' first year as a full-fledged member of Division I-A in 2002. Led by sophomore quarterback Dan Orlovsky, they showed vast improvement over the previous two seasons, despite starting the season losing six of the first eight games. They closed Memorial Stadium in fashion by routing the last two opponents, Florida Atlantic and Kent State, by a combined score of 124–35. The 63 points scored against Kent State in the Memorial Stadium finale, was the most the Huskies ever scored in the 50 years of playing in the stadium. They concluded a successful season by defeating Navy, 38–0, and Iowa State, 37–20. The victory over Iowa State was the Huskies' first win over a bowl-bound team. Connecticut was originally scheduled to join the Big East as a football member in 2005. However, following the departure of Miami, Virginia Tech, the Huskies' entrance into the Big East was expedited by one year. Boston College would leave the Big East at the conclusion of the 2004 season.[13] The success continued in 2003, when Connecticut began play in Rentschler Field. They would finish the season with an overall record of 9–3. They opened the season with their first victory vs. a Big Ten team (34–10 over Indiana) and the final game of the season provided their first victory over an ACC opponent, when they defeated Wake Forest, 51–17. It was only the third time that a non-conference team had scored over 50 points in an ACC stadium. Despite the stellar record, the Huskies were not invited to play in a bowl game, largely due to their lack of conference affiliation. The Huskies played their first Big East conference game on September 17, 2004, when they dropped a 27–7 decision at Boston College. Their first Big East conference win came only 13 days later, when they defeated Pittsburgh 29–17. They completed their first season in the conference in 5th place with a record of 3–3. That year's overall record of 8–4 was enough to garner an invitation to the 2004 Motor City Bowl, the first bowl invitation in the school's history. The attendance of 52,552 was, at the time, a record crowd for the Bowl. The Huskies were hit hard by graduation and injuries in the 2005 and 2006 seasons. The program opened one of the best and newest college football facilities in 2006 with the completion of the $57.9 million (165,000 sq. ft.) Burton Family Football Complex & Mark R. Shenkman Training Center.[14] The 2007 season saw a quick turnaround with the Huskies' first ever Big East Conference football title, which they shared with West Virginia. For the first time UConn beat a ranked opponent at home, defeating South Florida 22–15. UConn participated in the Meineke Car Care Bowl losing to Wake Forest 24–10. That was followed up with consecutive 8–5 seasons in 2008 and 2009 with wins in both of their bowl games (over Buffalo and the SEC's South Carolina). The team was hit hard in 2009 by the on-campus murder of junior cornerback Jasper Howard, who was stabbed by a non-student outside a dance following their homecoming game win over Louisville. UConn struggled following his death, dropping their next three games and falling to 1–4 in-conference, but got a major win to break the streak at Notre Dame, a victory quoted by Coach Randy Edsall as being the program's "Best Win".[15] The game ball from that victory was sent to Howard's mother in Miami, one of many tributes throughout the year for the fallen player. The team honored Howard prior to every game through the 2010 season, which would have been his senior year. The 2010 season brought a second Big East Championship in four years and a trip to the 2011 Fiesta Bowl. After a loss in the Fiesta Bowl, to Oklahoma, Edsall did not fly home with or tell his players that he was leaving the UConn football program. He instead took a separate flight to Maryland to become their new head coach. It had also been noted in the media that Edsall's relationship with then-athletic director Jeff Hathaway had been strained for several years. Two weeks after Edsall left for Maryland and after nearly seven years away from college football, Connecticut native Paul Pasqualoni was hired away as defensive coordinator from the Dallas Cowboys to lead the UConn football program, by the soon to be dismissed AD Hathaway. The Big East's name changed in 2013 to the American Athletic Conference as a result of the non-FBS split that took place as part of the conference's three-way realignment between 2010 and 2013. Three members moved to the ACC as full members, Notre Dame went the ACC as a partial, Rutgers to the Big Ten and West Virginia to the Big 12. With the seven non-FBS basketball schools buying the Big East conference name for their own newly formed conference. Two teams departing to the ACC, Syracuse and Pittsburgh left the Big East with losing records against the Huskies in football.[citation needed] Following two seasons of mediocrity and a struggling offense, Pasqualoni was forced to replace his lifelong colleague George DeLeone as the offensive coordinator, just as he did prior to them both being fired at Syracuse. Pasqualoni named T. J. Weist as his OC for 2013. But Pasqualoni and Deleone (now his OL coach) were both fired after starting 0–4 with UConn's first loss as full D-I member to an FCS team, Towson 33–18 and following a humiliating defeat to Buffalo (41–12), which UConn had never lost to (8–0) as an FBS team. Weist was named the interim head coach and finished the season strong on a 3-game winning streak after starting out 0–5 and totally revamping the offense free of Pasqualoni's control. Though Weist was considered for the head coaching job, UConn AD Warde Manuel announced Notre Dame defensive coordinator and Broyles Award winner Bob Diaco as the new UConn head coach for the 2014 season. After a complete tear down of the program in 2014, which would lead to Diaco finishing the year with only around 60 scholarship players available and needing to use a dozen true freshman, the team finished 2–10. The 2015 season resulted in a revitalization for the program as they finished 6–6 and became bowl eligible for the first time since the 2010 season. On December 26, 2016, UConn announced that Diaco, who posted his 3rd straight losing year with a 3–9 record would be fired effective January 2, 2017. By not making the move immediately, the school saved $1.6 million in buyout expenses.[16] He was replaced by former coach Edsall, making his return to the program after six years.[17] Following a 3–9 third season with the Huskies, Diaco was terminated at the end of the 2016 season.[16] His replacement, Randy Edsall, returning to the program after six years, would not find similar success in his second go-around. In 2019, after several years of losing records with a $41 million sports created deficit, UConn made the choice to leave the AAC and rejoin the current edition of the Big East.[citation needed] This was seemingly a basketball move because the Big East does not have football.[citation needed] The path would be to play as an independent.[citation needed] The UConn football team left the American and became independent in August 2020 as a result of UConn's other sports rejoining the Big East, which does not sponsor football.[18] UConn cancelled their 2020 season due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Their first season competing independently was in 2021. After three straight losing campaigns and a season cancelled by the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, Edsall elected to retire after a 0–2 start in 2021.[19] To replace Edsall, UConn hired Jim L. Mora. In his first season with the team, Mora would lead the Huskies to a surprising 6–6 regular season record, highlighted by an upset victory over then-No. 19 Liberty. Bowl-eligible for the first time since 2015, UConn was selected to play in the 2022 Myrtle Beach Bowl against Marshall, in a rematch of their last bowl game.[20] In the 2024 season, UConn had an 8–4 record, their first winning season since 2010. They were invited to compete in the Fenway Bowl against North Carolina.[21] In 2010, Connecticut had 16 players named to the Big East All-Academic Football Team,[22] an honor which requires a cumulative Grade Point Average (GPA) of at least a 3.0 in a minimum of two semesters. And several times UConn was ranked as one of the top bowl teams in the country per the annual Graduation Gap Bowl report.[23][24] In 2015, the team was honored by AF Coaches Assoc. for academic achievement and the 990 single year APR score in 2014–15 under head coach Diaco was also the highest in school history. Connecticut has participated in seven bowl games, with the Huskies garnering a record of 3–4.[25] Connecticut has won 26 conference championships, 17 shared and 9 outright.[citation needed] † Co-champions The Huskies have won one division title, which they shared with UMass. † Co-champions The Yankee Conference rivalry dates back to 1897. The rivalry became dormant in 1999 as UConn moved up to the FBS and UMass remained at the FCS level. The rivalry would be revived in UMass's FBS debut, a 37–0 win for the Huskies. Since 2018, each school has won two of the four contests. The football rivalry dates back to 1897 and was centered around the Ramnapping Trophy after UConn students stole the URI mascot in 1934. The teams played nearly every year until the end of the Yankee Conference. Once UConn moved up to the FBS, the teams seldom play as Rhode Island remains an FCS program. Since 2000, there have been only three meetings: a UConn (52–7) win in 2006, a UConn (52–10) win in 2009, and a back-and-forth 56–49 UConn victory in 2018. Better known for their men's basketball rivalry, the football rivalry between UConn and bordering-state foe Syracuse dates back to 2004 and has been played 12 times.[26][27] The teams were members of the old Big East until Syracuse left in 2012 to join the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) in all sports.[28][29] Since becoming a non-conference matchup, the game has been played intermittently with the next meeting coming in 2024.[30] In 1997, the Big East Conference gave the University of Connecticut and Villanova University a December 31 deadline to decide if they were going to upgrade their respective football programs and join the Big East football conference.[31] Villanova, a private institution, declined the invitation. However, in October 1997, the University of Connecticut Board of Trustees overwhelmingly endorsed, by a vote of sixteen to one, the football team's plan to upgrade the program to Division I-A status.[32] Part of the plan would be to build a new stadium, as the current stadium, Memorial Stadium, fell well below the minimum occupancy level of 30,000, as set by the NCAA. Originally, the new stadium was to be built on campus. However, the enthusiasm toward the new stadium quickly faded as the estimated expenses rose, the idea of an on-campus stadium was tabled, and the upgrade of the program was put on hold by the Connecticut state legislature.[33] A year later, the stadium issue was rehashed during an attempt to bring the New England Patriots to Hartford, Connecticut. A proposed 70,000 seat, open-air stadium in downtown Hartford would also serve as the home of the Huskies football team.[34] The plans for this stadium also fell through and the Patriots announced that they would remain in Foxboro, Massachusetts. Eventually, a new site emerged across the Connecticut River in East Hartford, when Pratt & Whitney donated land on the old Rentschler Airfield to the state for purposes of building an off-campus football stadium which is 20 miles away from the main campus. The Huskies play their home football games at Pratt & Whitney Stadium at Rentschler Field in East Hartford, Connecticut, an off-campus facility located 20 miles (32 km) to the west of the main campus and only 3 miles east of the new Downtown Hartford-Uconn campus. The inaugural game took place on August 30, 2003, when Connecticut defeated the Indiana Hoosiers 34–10. Since the opening, Connecticut has enjoyed a decided home field advantage, posting a 68–59 record when playing at Rentschler. In 2007, the Huskies completed their home season winning each of their seven home games, becoming only the second Big East team to compile a 7–0 home record. The stadium played to an average of 97% near capacity crowds for eight years (2003–2010), prior to Paul Pasqualoni's arrival and during the Big East. The Huskies on-campus home is at the Burton Family Football Complex on Stadium Road in Storrs, Connecticut. It contains the coaches' offices, team meeting rooms, video facilities, dining hall and student-athlete lounge. Construction began in the fall of 2004 and it officially opened in July 2006. The building is named after Robert Burton, who in 2002 made a donation of $2.5 million to the University of Connecticut. The original location of the building was to be where Memorial Stadium stands.[35] However, it was later decided to construct the building across the street. Alongside the Burton Family Football Complex is the 85,000-square-foot (7,900 m2) Mark R. Shenkman Training Center. The indoor training center includes a full-length football field and an 18,000-square-foot (1,700 m2) strength and conditioning center.[36] The training center was made possible by a $2.5 million gift from Connecticut businessman and UConn alum Mark Shenkman.[37] Construction of the Mark R. Shenkman Training Center and the Burton Family Football Complex were handled in tandem by HOK Sport (now Populous) and JCJ Architecture. Upon completion in the summer of 2006, both buildings were granted a LEED silver designation. They are the first buildings on the University of Connecticut campus, and the first football facilities in the nation to be certified as a "green building."[38] [39] [40][41] The Brian Kozlowski Award was first awarded in 1998. It honors the former UConn Husky and former New York Giants, Atlanta Falcons, and Washington Redskins tight end, Brian Kozlowski, who through hard work, effort and dedication has been able to have a lengthy NFL career.[48]: 86 Announced schedules as of August 26, 2024.[49]

UConn football.title: 2024 UConn Huskies football team - Wikipedia
UConn football.content: The 2024 UConn Huskies football team represented the University of Connecticut (UConn) as an independent during the 2024 NCAA Division I FBS football season. The Huskies were led by Jim L. Mora in his third year as the head coach. The Huskies played their home games at Pratt & Whitney Stadium at Rentschler Field, located in East Hartford, Connecticut.[1] After a win over UAB on November 9, which they erased a 17-point deficit after the half, the Huskies secured their first winning season since 2010.[2] After their win in the Fenway Bowl, the Huskies won their first bowl game since 2009. [3][4] Roster Last update: August 10, 2024 at SECU Stadium, College Park, Maryland Second quarter Third quarter Fourth quarter at Pratt & Whitney Stadium at Rentschler Field, East Hartford, Connecticut Second quarter Third quarter Fourth quarter at Wallace Wade Stadium • Durham, North Carolina Second quarter Third quarter Fourth quarter at Rentschler Field • East Hartford, Connecticut Second quarter Third quarter Fourth quarter Statistics at Rentschler Field • East Hartford, Connecticut Second quarter Third quarter Fourth quarter Statistics at Rentschler Field • East Hartford, Connecticut Second quarter Third quarter Fourth quarter Statistics at Rentschler Field • East Hartford, Connecticut Second quarter Third quarter Fourth quarter Statistics at Rentschler Field • East Hartford, Connecticut Second quarter Third quarter Fourth quarter Statistics at Rentschler Field • East Hartford, Connecticut Second quarter Third quarter Fourth quarter Statistics at Protective Stadium • Birmingham, Alabama Second quarter Third quarter Fourth quarter Statistics at JMA Wireless Dome • Syracuse, New York Second quarter Third quarter Fourth quarter Statistics at Warren McGuirk Alumni Stadium, Hadley, Massachusetts Second quarter Third quarter Fourth quarter at Fenway Park • Boston, Massachusetts

James Conner.title: James Conner (American football) - Wikipedia
James Conner.content: James Earl Conner (born May 5, 1995) is an American professional football running back for the Arizona Cardinals of the National Football League (NFL). He played college football for the Pittsburgh Panthers. In 2014, he garnered AFCA first-team All-American honors and was awarded the ACC Player of the Year. He was selected by the Pittsburgh Steelers in the third round of the 2017 NFL draft. Conner attended McDowell High School in Erie, Pennsylvania.[1] He was a running back and defensive lineman on the Trojans football team.[1] As a senior, he rushed for 1,680 yards on 155 carries and 26 touchdowns. He committed to play college football at the University of Pittsburgh in August 2012.[2] As a true freshman in 2013, Conner played in 12 of 13 games. He made his collegiate debut during the Panthers' season opening loss to Florida State and had eight carries for 34 yards.[3] The following week, he scored his first career touchdown against New Mexico and finished the win with 12 carries, 119 rushing yards, and a season-high two touchdowns.[4] On December 26, 2013, Conner had a season-high 26 carries for 226 yards and a touchdown during a 30–27 victory over Bowling Green in the Little Caesars Bowl,[5] He was named the 2013 Little Caesars Pizza Bowl MVP.[6] He led the team in rushing yards with 799 and rushing touchdowns with eight.[7][8][9] Conner's 229 rushing yards broke Tony Dorsett's school record for rushing yards in a bowl game.[10][11] Conner started his sophomore season rushing for 153 yards on 14 carries and scored a season-high four touchdowns in the season-opening 62–0 win over Delaware.[12] On November 1, 2014, Conner rushed for a career-high 263 rushing yards on a career-high 38 attempts and scored three touchdowns during a 51–48 double-overtime loss to No. 24 Duke.[13] The next game, he passed 200 yards rushing for a second consecutive game with 30 carries for 220 yards and career-high-tying four touchdowns in a loss to North Carolina.[14] In his sophomore season in 2014, Conner rushed for 1,765 yards on 298 attempts and set an Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) record with 26 rushing touchdowns.[15] He led the ACC in rushing yards and ranked 7th in the Football Bowl Subdivision.[16][17] At the end of the season, he was named the ACC Player of the Year[18] and garnered American Football Coaches Association first-team All-American honors. On September 5, 2015, Conner tore his MCL during the Panthers' season opening 45–37 victory over Youngstown State.[19] He finished the game with eight carries for 77 rushing yards and scored two rushing touchdowns but missed the rest of his junior season.[20] He was also diagnosed with Hodgkin's Lymphoma during the rehab process and was finally cancer-free during the off-season.[21] Conner played in the Panthers' season-opener against Villanova and finished the victory with 17 carries for 53 yards and a touchdown while also accounting for three receptions for 15 yards and scored his first career touchdown reception.[22] The next game, Conner had 22 attempts for 117 rushing yards and a rushing touchdown in a 42–39 victory over Penn State. He also had four receptions, 29 receiving yards, and a touchdown reception against Penn State.[23] On September 17, 2016, Conner had a season-high 24 carries for 111 rushing yards and a touchdown during a 38–45 loss to Oklahoma State.[24] On October 27, 2016, he had 19 carries, a season-high 141 rushing yards, and three touchdowns in a 36–39 loss to No. 25 Virginia Tech.[25][26] On December 10, 2016, Conner announced via Twitter that he intended to apply for early eligibility for the 2017 NFL draft as an underclassman and forgo his senior year at Pitt. Underclassmen had to apply for the draft by January 16, 2017.[27] Conner attended the NFL Scouting Combine, but chose to perform only the 40-yard dash, broad jump, vertical jump, and bench press. He completed the three-cone drill, short shuttle, and positional drills at Pitt's Pro Day to finish his combine performance. At the conclusion of the pre-draft process, Conner was projected to be a fifth or sixth round pick by NFL draft scouts and experts.[28] Conner was ranked the 12th best running back available in the draft by Sports Illustrated and the 15th best running back by DraftScout.com.[29] The Pittsburgh Steelers selected Conner in the third round with the 105th overall pick in the 2017 NFL Draft.[32] Conner was the eighth running back selected in the draft.[33] He had the top selling NFL jersey throughout July, beating all rookies, as well as Marshawn Lynch, Von Miller, Dak Prescott, and Tom Brady.[34] On May 11, 2017, the Steelers signed Conner to a four-year, $3.16 million contract that includes a signing bonus of $706,288.[35][36] Conner entered training camp competing with veterans Knile Davis and Fitzgerald Toussaint for the vacant backup running back position left by DeAngelo Williams. Davis and Toussaint were released during final roster cutdowns, and Steelers head coach Mike Tomlin named Conner the backup to Le'Veon Bell to begin the regular season.[37] Conner made his NFL debut in the season-opener at the Cleveland Browns and had four carries for 11 yards in a 21–18 victory.[38] In Week 4, he had four carries for a season-high 26 rushing yards in a 26–9 victory at the Baltimore Ravens. On December 19, 2017, he was placed on injured reserve due to an MCL injury that required surgery.[39] Conner finished his rookie season with 144 rushing yards on 32 carries.[40] Head coach Mike Tomlin named Conner the starting running back to begin the regular season after Le'Veon Bell's decision to indefinitely hold out due to a contract dispute over a long-term deal.[41] Conner made his first NFL start in the season-opener at the Browns and had 31 carries for 135 rushing yards and two touchdowns in a 21–21 tie. He scored his first NFL touchdown on a 4-yard run in the first quarter and also had five receptions for 47 yards. His 135-yard performance led all players in rushing yards during Week 1.[42] During Week 5 in a 41–17 victory over the Atlanta Falcons, he had 110 rushing yards and two rushing touchdowns to go along with four receptions for 75 yards.[43] In Week 6, a 28–21 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals, Conner had 111 rushing yards and two rushing touchdowns to go along with four receptions for 18 yards.[44] In Week 8, Conner had the best game of his career to date, rushing for 146 yards on 24 carries and two touchdowns as well as five receptions for 66 yards in a 33–18 rout of the Browns.[45] For his efforts, Conner was named the American Football Conference (AFC) Offensive Player of the Week along with AFC Offensive Player of the Month for the month of October.[46][47] In the following game, against the Ravens, he had 107 rushing yards, 56 receiving yards, and a receiving touchdown in the 23–16 victory.[48] In Week 13, against the Los Angeles Chargers, he suffered a lower leg injury that sidelined him for a few weeks.[49] It was announced on December 18, 2018, that Conner was selected to the 2019 Pro Bowl, his first, and also named the starting running back for the AFC Pro Bowl Team.[50] He returned for the regular season finale against the Cincinnati Bengals.[51] He finished the 2018 season with 973 rushing yards, 12 rushing touchdowns, 55 receptions, 497 receiving yards, and a receiving touchdown.[52] He was ranked 62nd by his fellow players on the NFL Top 100 Players of 2019.[53] In Week 2 against the Seattle Seahawks, Conner injured his knee and exited the game in the third quarter. Prior to being injured, Conner rushed 11 times for 33 yards and his first rushing touchdown of the year. Without Conner, the Steelers lost 26–28.[54] In Week 6 against the Chargers, Conner rushed 16 times for 41 yards and a touchdown and caught seven passes for 78 yards and a touchdown in the 24–17 win.[55] In Week 8 against the Miami Dolphins on Monday Night Football, Conner rushed 23 times for 145 yards and a touchdown before exiting the game with a shoulder injury. Without Conner, the Steelers won 27–14.[56] He was named the AFC Offensive Player of the Week for his performance.[57] Conner made his return from injury in Week 11 against the Browns on Thursday Night Football. In the game, Conner rushed five times for 10 yards and caught one pass for six yards before injuring his shoulder again in the first half. The Steelers eventually lost 21–7 without Conner.[58] Overall, Conner recorded 464 rushing yards and four rushing touchdowns to go along with 34 receptions for 251 receiving yards and three receiving touchdowns.[59] In Week 1 against the New York Giants on Monday Night Football, Conner rushed six times for nine yards before exiting the game due to an ankle injury. The Steelers won the game 26–16 without Conner in the lineup.[60] Conner bounced back in Week 2 against the Denver Broncos with 106 rushing yards and a rushing touchdown in the 26–21 victory.[61] He recorded 18 carries for 109 rushing yards in the 28–21 victory over the Houston Texans in Week 3.[62] In Week 6 against the Browns, he had 20 carries for 101 rushing yards and one rushing touchdown in the 38–7 victory.[63] On November 28, 2020, Conner was placed on the reserve/COVID-19 list after testing positive for the virus,[64] and activated on December 9.[65] He finished the 2020 season with 169 carries for 721 rushing yards and six rushing touchdowns to go along with 35 receptions for 215 receiving yards.[66] In the Wild Card Round of the playoffs against the Browns, Conner rushed for 37 yards and a touchdown and caught five passes for 30 yards during the 48–37 loss.[67] On April 13, 2021, Conner signed a one-year deal with the Arizona Cardinals.[68] In Week 9, Conner led the Cardinals over the San Francisco 49ers with 173 scrimmage yards and three touchdowns.[69] In Week 14, against the Los Angeles Rams, he had 125 scrimmage yards and two rushing touchdowns.[70] He finished the season as the Cardinals leading rusher with 752 yards and finished second in the league with a career-high 15 rushing touchdowns.[71][72][73] He was named to the Pro Bowl.[74] He was ranked 80th by his fellow players on the NFL Top 100 Players of 2022.[75] On March 14, 2022, Conner signed a three-year contract extension with the Cardinals.[76] In Week 12, against the Chargers, he had 25 carries for 120 rushing yards and one receiving touchdown in the 25–24 loss.[77] In the 2022 season, Conner had 183 carries for 782 rushing yards and seven rushing touchdowns to go along with 46 receptions for 300 receiving yards and one receiving touchdown.[78] In Week 5, Conner suffered a knee injury and was placed on injured reserve on October 10, 2023.[79] On November 11, the Cardinals reactivated him back on their active roster.[80] In Week 13, against the Steelers, Conner had 25 carries for 105 yards and two touchdowns in the win.[81] In Week 17, against the Eagles, he had 26 carries for 128 yards, one rushing touchdown, and one receiving touchdown in the win.[82] In Week 18, against the Seattle Seahawks, he had 27 carries for a career-high 150 rushing yards and one touchdown. This performance put him over 1,000 yards for the first time in his career.[83] He finished the 2023 season with 208 carries for 1,040 rushing yards and seven rushing touchdowns to go with 27 receptions for 165 receiving yards and two receiving touchdowns in 13 games and starts.[84] On November 30, 2024, Conner and the Cardinals agreed to a two–year, $19 million contract extension.[85] Conner was raised by his parents, Kelly Patterson and Glen Conner Sr. and is the youngest of five brothers. [86] He majored in communication at Pitt.[87] Glen Jr. also plays football, a defensive lineman with his local Erie Express professional team in the Gridiron Developmental Football League (GDFL). On April 22, 2019, the Express honored Glen as their "Defensive Player of the Week" with seven tackles, three tackles for loss (−16 yards), three sacks, and an interception in their 30–6 victory over the Westmoreland Wolves.[88] On December 4, 2015, Conner announced he was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma. Despite this, he said "I choose to not fear cancer... I will play football again."[89] After tearing his MCL during the Panthers' first game of 2015, Conner attended rehab and began experiencing excessive fatigue and other symptoms, leading doctors to perform a chest x-ray that revealed Hodgkin's Lymphoma.[27] He endured 12 rounds of chemotherapy and completed his last chemo appointment on May 9, 2016. During his treatment, Conner continued to participate in non-contact drills with the Pittsburgh Panthers football team as much as his body would allow.[90] Conner appeared on the April 21, 2016, episode of The Ellen DeGeneres Show and met Kansas City Chiefs' safety Eric Berry, who also overcame Hodgkin's lymphoma and whom Conner saw as an inspirational figure. During Conner's treatment, the two players had spoken via text message but had never met in person.[90] On May 23, 2016, Conner announced on Twitter that he was cancer free.[91] During the 2018 season, Conner began growing a mullet, which became popular among Steeler fans and fully embracing the Yinzer culture with the hairstyle.[92] Conner joined many other Pittsburgh natives and/or sports stars that have sported the hairstyle, most prominently former Pittsburgh Penguins superstar Jaromír Jágr.[93]

James Conner.title: A Letter to NFL GMs
James Conner.content: James Conner Arizona Cardinals Dear NFL GMs: My name is James Conner. I’m a running back who was born and raised in Erie, Pennsylvania. My sophomore year at Pitt I scored 26 touchdowns and was named ACC Player of the Year. But it’s more likely that you know me for one very specific thing. Cancer. It’s cool. That’s totally reasonable. I mean, at this point I’m pretty much recognized around the world as “that football player who battled Hodgkin’s and then came back to play the following year.” I went on Ellen and sat for a bunch of TV spots with dramatic lighting and sad piano music. So I understand. I’ve come to realize that me being a cancer survivor is something I’ll never get away from. It’s a part of my story, no doubt. But I’m writing you today to let you know that I am more than the guy who beat cancer. I’m writing to tell you some things that you don’t know about me. When I was a junior at McDowell High, back in Erie, I played mostly defensive end. I was sacking guys left and right, but I guess college coaches weren’t all that impressed, because I wasn’t getting any looks from recruiters. Pretty much no one knew who I was, and they weren’t really trying to find out, either. These days you hear a lot about five-star recruits. Well … I was a two-star recruit back then. I’m not positive, but I don’t think they go any lower than that. I don’t know of any one-star guys. I think a one-star guy is just like … a guy. Two-star recruits have to put in work. So that summer after my junior season I felt like I had to take matters into my own hands. I had read about a prospect camp at Pitt — which is around a two-hour car ride from Erie —and figured that I’d show up and try to make an impression on the coaches there. The only problem was that the entry fee was fifty bucks … and I didn’t have fifty bucks. I was a two-star recruit back then. I’m not positive, but I don’t think they go any lower than that. My mom was working real hard at the time to be able to pay our bills, and I knew it would be tough. So, at first, I didn’t even want to ask her for the money. Eventually, I told her that I wanted to play college football more than anything in the world, and that all I needed was one shot to show those coaches what I could do. “So how much is it, James?” “Fifty, Mom.” “That’s a lot of money for a football camp.” I explained to her that I knew this was my big shot, and how it would mean everything if she could just spot me the $50. She has always believed in me, so after we talked about it, she said I could go. I drove down to Pitt on June 6, 2012, and here’s what I did when I got there. Over and over again, I did that to dudes — just spinnin’ off linemen, beating guys around the edge with my speed, running people over. I got a scholarship offer on the spot. Full ride. No questions asked. I put that work in, and it paid off. Not many people know that I started out as a defensive player — that’s one more thing I can do. After I committed to Pitt, I switched to running back for my senior season of high school ball, and I felt like I was performing at a very high level. So that’s when the Pitt coaches decided they might be able to use me there. My response when they asked me to switch from defensive end to running back was the same as it’s always been when I’m called on to do something to help my team win. “Whatever you need me to do, Coach, I’m in!” And that just so happens to be the same thing I said when I was asked to switch back to defensive end this past year for a few plays when we needed to get some pressure on the quarterback against Virginia. There are some incredible running backs in this draft, some really talented guys, but I’m pretty sure no other back was out there doing stuff like that last year. And, speaking of last season, before I go any further it’s probably a good time for me to share a secret with you that I didn’t really discuss with anyone while our games were taking place. This is another thing not too many people know about me…. I was probably at about 60% going into last season. Now, I definitely got stronger and better with each game. But, yeah, that’s just real talk. Sixty percent. If that. I’d talk to my doctor each week, and he encouraged my determination. For most people who get 12 rounds of chemotherapy, it takes about six to eight months to recover — layin’ low, no lifting, just trying to gain back strength. With me, as soon as physically possible, I was out there with my brothers, with a mask over my mouth and a port still embedded in my chest, participating in workouts. Early on, because I only had two months to prepare for the season, it was extremely difficult for me to be at my best. To be honest with you, I’d be tired just running out the tunnel. Those first couple of games really took their toll on me. But by the time we got to the fifth game of the season, I was starting to feel normal again. And when the 10th game of the year arrived, against Clemson at Death Valley, I was hype. I felt really good and turned up! That Clemson game was just flat-out incredible. And, you know what? I’m sure you’ve got a ton of players to review before the draft, so if you’re pressed for time and want to get a good sense of what I can do on the football field, just cue up the game tape from that one and press play. On the road, against the team that would go on to win the national championship — the team with the best defense in college football — I put up more than 130 yards and two touchdowns on the ground. I also caught three passes for nearly 60 yards. It was a pretty emotional experience because it was the first time in a while that the game felt like it used to for me. Early in the first quarter, I collided with Clemson linebacker Ben Boulware so violently that I actually split his face mask. I had a bunch of memorable runs and catches during that game, but the play that really sticks out to me from that one is a carry I had with about five minutes left. We were down by eight. I took a handoff in the gun on a zone play designed to go to the left. The hole closed up fast, so I cut it all the way back, threw a stiff-arm and took it to the house. To make a big run like that near the end of the game, and help our team give Clemson its only loss of the season? That was probably the best experience I had on the football field during my four years at Pitt. It was also the moment in time when I knew I was finally all the way back. So, now that I’ve told you some things you probably didn’t know about me, it’s time for me to really make my case for why you should spend an early pick on me in this draft. First off: I’m 100% healthy. I have a clean scan showing I’m still cancer free. The knee injury I suffered a few years ago is fully healed, and I played the whole season on it without any pain. I don’t even think about it anymore. My endurance is all the way back, too. I feel good. All winter and spring, I trained hard to get back to the shape I was in during my All-America season. When I was doing my chemo treatments last year, I had to take some medications that resulted in my weight jumping all the way up to 260 pounds — I lost most of my muscle mass and gained a bunch of fat. I worked most of that off during the season, but when I started training for the combine, I was still at about 18% body fat. I’m down to around 7% now. Just call me ‘Beast Mode 2.0.’ I’m quicker than I’ve ever been — just lighter on my feet. But, you know, I’m still big. Believe me. No one’s ever gonna be psyched about having to tackle me, bet that. If you’re looking for a tough, hard-nosed back who wears down defenses, I’m your man. I know you guys love comps, so my favorite running back of all time is Marshawn Lynch, and that’s the best comparison I can give you. He’s always got such amazing willpower to go along with an “I’m not gonna be denied” mentality, and those are two things I bring to the table every time I suit up. I’m not going down on first contact. It’s just not gonna happen. I’m breaking tackles and fighting for extra yards every time I get the ball, just like Marshawn. Just call me “Beast Mode 2.0.” (As long as that’s cool with Marshawn, of course.) I’m next in line, and ready to follow in his footsteps. Anything you need from a back, I can do. Obviously I’m gonna run hard. That’s a given. But if you also want somebody who can pass-protect and catch the ball out of the backfield, I’ve shown over and over again that I can do those things extremely well. Plus, because of how I play, and the intensity I bring to the game, I’m a guy that people want to line up with — a leader. And, make no mistake about it: I’ve never had it easy. Ever since I was a two-star recruit from Erie, I’ve had to scratch and claw and outwork people, and I’ve done nothing but prove doubters wrong time and time again. So I’m more confident than ever that before all is said and done, people are going to know me more as a great football player than as a cancer survivor. I don’t set little goals. I mean, I’m trying to be in the Hall of Fame one day. That’s where I’m looking to take this. That’s where my head’s at. If that goal sounds overly ambitious, or like an unrealistic dream, just think about what I went through to get here. When the pandemic started, I guess we all needed to find hobbies to help us pass the time. For me, it was reading. This has been a pretty big year for me — tra Channing Frye and Iman Shumpert are back to explain the stakes, place bets and analyze the most valuable players in the NBA Finals. Jessica Mendoza's greatest pride is her background. The Olympic Gold Medalist shines light on her Hispanic heritage fueling her career. © 2024 Minute Media - All Rights Reserved

James Conner.title: James Conner
James Conner.content: Experience: 8 years Height: 6-1 Age: 29 Weight: 233 lbs College: Pittsburgh NoteCARDS: NoteCARDS: Pro Career: Selected by Pittsburgh in the third round (105th overall) of the 2017 NFL Draft and spent his first four seasons with the Steelers. Signed a one-year contract with the Cardinals as an unrestricted free agent on 4/13/21. Re-signed with Arizona on a three-year contract through the 2024 season on 3/14/22. 2023: Started all 13 games he appeared in (missed four games due to a knee injury) and ran for a career-high 1,040 yards on 208 carries (career-high 5.0 avg.) and seven TDs ... also added 27 catches for 165 yards and two TDs ... had 11 runs of 20+ yards, the most in the NFL ... also ranked second in the league in rushing yards per game (80.0) and third in runs of 10+ yards (31) ... had four 100-yard games, becoming the first Cardinal since 2016 to have 4+ games with 100+ rushing yards in a season ... started the season opener @ Was (9/10) where he had 14 carries for 62 yards to go along with five catches for eight yards ... rushed 23 times for 106 yards and a TD vs. NYG (9/17); it marked the 11th game with 100+ rushing yards in his career; had three rushes of 17+ (17, 21, 22) in a single game for just the second time in his career ... rushed for 98 yards and a TD on 14 carries (7.0 avg.) vs. Dal (9/24); it marked the first time in his career that he averaged 7.0+ yards per carry in a game in which he had more than two rush attempts ... had 11 carries for 52 yards and a four-yard reception @ SF (10/1) ... had six carries for 46 yards, including a 35-yard rush that matched the second-longest run of his career, vs. Cin. (10/8) before leaving the game due to injury ... missed four games on injured reserve with a knee injury ... ran for 73 yards on 16 carries (4.6 avg.) vs. Atl (11/12) ... rushed for 62 yards on 14 carries (4.4 avg.) @ Hou (11/19) ... ran six times for 27 yards and had four catches for five yards vs. LAR (11/26) ... rushed for 105 yards and two TDs on 25 carries (4.2 avg.) @ Pit (12/3); it marked the fifth time in his career and his first time with the Cardinals that he rushed for 100+ yards and 2+ TDs in a game; it also marked his 12th career game and the seventh time as a member of the Cardinals rushing for 2+ TDs; his seven games with multiple rushing TDs since 2021 are the third most in the NFL during that span; the performance earned him FedEX Ground Player of the Week as he became the first Cardinal to win the award since 2019 (RB Kenyan Drake) ... rushed for 86 yards and a TD on 14 carries vs. SF (12/17), including a 44-yard carry which marked the second-longest run of his career; the TD run marked his 27th with the Cardinals, only five players in franchise history have more rushing TDs ... rushed for 45 yards on 12 carries and added five receptions for 67 yards and a TD @ Chi (12/24); led the team in both rushing and receiving yards; had 100+ scrimmage yards in a game for the 23rd time in his career and the fourth time this season; the TD catch marked his first of the season ... had 26 carries for 128 yards and a TD on the ground to pair with a five-yard TD catch @ Phi (12/31), it marked the first game of his NFL career with 100+ rushing yards, a rushing TD and a receiving TD; surpassed 1,000 scrimmage yards in 2023 marking his third consecutive season doing so joining Ottis Anderson (1979-81) as the only players in Cardinals history to have 1,000+ scrimmage yards in each of their first three seasons with the team; the rushing TD marked the 50th of his career making Conner one of eight active players with 50+ rushing TDs in his career; the day also marked Conner's ninth multi-TD game since joining Arizona in 2021, which is tied for the fourth-most games in the NFL in that span ... rushed for a career-high 150 yards, including a career-long 29-yard TD run on 27 carries (5.6 avg.) in the season finale vs. Sea (1/7/24); reached a new career-high 1,040 rushing yards on the season, surpassing the 1,000-yard milestone for the first time in his NFL career. 2022: Finished the 2022 season with 1,082 scrimmage yards in 13 games played, marking the second straight season with 1,000+ yards ... rushed for 782 yards on 183 carries and scored seven TDs ... finished the season having scored 26 total TDs in his first 28 regular season games played with the Cardinals, the second-most in franchise history in a player's first 28 games with the team (RB David Johnson - 28) ... also added 46 receptions for 300 yards and one TD ... rushed for 26 yards on 10 carries and scored a TD in season opener vs. KC (9/11); TD gave him 19 total TDs in 16 regular season games with the Cardinals; in NFL history, only Hall of Famers Gale Sayers (24 w/ Bears), Randy Moss (23 w/ Patriots), Jim Brown (20 w/ Browns) and Eric Dickerson (20 w/ Rams) had more TDs in their first 16 games with a team; had 16 rushing TDs in first 16 regular season games with the Cardinals ... had 55 yards rushing on nine carries and hauled in an eight yard reception vs. Phi (10/9); did not play in second half (hip) ... inactive (hip) @ Sea (10/16), vs. NO (10/20) and @ Min (10/30) ... finished with 86 total yards (69 rushing and 17 receiving) and two rushing TDs in Cardinals win @ LAR (11/13) ... rushed for 42 yards on 14 attempts with a TD and caught two passes for 12 yards vs. SF (11/21) ... posted his first 100-yard rushing game with the Cardinals after rushing for 120 yards on 25 carries vs. LAC (11/27); also had three receptions for 20 yards and a TD ... rushed for 85 yards on 15 carries vs. NE (12/12) and had six receptions for 29 yards ... rushed 16 times for 63 yards and one TD @ Den (12/18) and had three receptions for 28 yards ... rushed 15 times for 79 yards and recorded Arizona's lone TD vs. TB (12/25); marked the sixth consecutive game in which he has at least one TD, tying the third-longest streak in franchise history; also added eight receptions for 41 yards vs. the Bucs ... amassed 79 yards off 16 carries @ Atl (1/1/23); marked fourth time in five games he had 75+ rushing yards; also had three receptions for 31 yards; after surpassing 100 yards from scrimmage vs. the Falcons, reached 1,000+ yards from scrimmage for the second straight year ... inactive @ SF (1/8/23). 2021: Named to his second career Pro Bowl, and first with the Cardinals, after ranking third in the NFL with 18 total TDs and tied for second with 15 rushing TDs; both marks represented the second-best single-season totals in franchise history ... totaled 752 yards and 15 TDs on 202 carries and added 375 yards and three TDs on 37 receptions in 15 regular season games ... also scored AZ's lone TD in the Wild Card contest … gained a team-high 43 rushing yards on 11 attempts and had two rushing TDs for his first points as a Cardinal @ Jax (9/26) ... rushed for 50 yards and two TDs on 18 carries and added 16 receiving yards on two receptions @ LAR (10/3); combined with his two-TD performance in Week 3, had four rushing TDs in a two-game stretch; marked the third time in his career posting back-to-back games with multiple TDs and his first time since Games 5-7 of the 2018 season; became the third Cardinals player in 22 years to have multiple rushing TDs in back-to-back games ... ran for 29 yards and one TD on a team-high 10 carries while adding an eight yard reception out of the backfield vs. SF (10/10) ... rushed for 96 yards and two TDs on 21 carries (4.6 avg.) while adding 77 yards and a TD on five receptions @ SF (11/7); joined Dallas RB Ezekiel Elliott (@ Pit 11/13/16) as the only players in the last six seasons (2016-21) to have: 95+ yards and 2+ TDs rushing & 75+ yards and 1+ TD receiving in a single game; became just the third player in franchise history with 10+ rushing TDs in the first nine games of a season; joined Tim Hightower (10 in 2008) and Ernie Nevers (10 in 1929) as the only players in Cardinals history to have 10+ rushing TDs in their first season with the team ... led the team in carries (10) and rushing yards (39) for one TD and added three receptions for 25 yards vs. Car (11/14) … led the team with 62 rushing yards on 21 attempts with one TD and added five receptions for 37 yards @ Sea (11/21); it was his fifth consecutive game with at least one rushing TD, tying the franchise record; Conner's TD was also his 12th rushing TD of the season, tying his career high (12 in 2018) ... led the team in rushing yards (75 on 20 attempts) and receiving yards (36 on two receptions) and added a receiving TD for an offense who became just the fifth team in NFL history to go at least five straight games without a turnover @ Chi (12/5); receiving TD was his 14th TD of the year, a new career high … scored both Arizona TDs on 13 carries for 31 yards and set career-bests in receptions (nine) and receiving yards (94) vs. LAR (12/13); marked his seventh consecutive game with a TD (rushing or receiving), tying the franchise record first set by John David Crow (1959-60) ... inactive (heel) vs. Ind (12/25) and @ Dal (1/2/22) ... in his return from injury, led the team with 52 yards and a TD on 15 carries and added 41 yards and a TD on six receptions vs. Sea (1/9/22) … recorded Arizona's only TD on a red zone rush attempt in his Cardinals playoff debut @ LAR (1/17/22). 2020: Started 11 of 13 games played during the regular season and also started in his postseason debut … rushed for 721 yards and six TDs on 169 carries (4.3 avg.) while adding 215 yards on 35 receptions … added 37 yards and a TD on 11 carries and 30 yards on five receptions in the playoffs … posted 100+ rushing yards in three games and surpassed 100+ scrimmage yards in four outings … started the season opener @ NYG (9/14) but left the game due to an ankle injury … in a Week 2 victory vs. Den (9/20), rushed for 106 yards and a TD on 16 carries and added two receptions for 15 yards; marked his seventh career 100-yard rushing performance; had a career-long 59-yard run with 1:30 remaining in the fourth quarter to seal the 26-21 win … had his second consecutive 100-yard rushing performance as he ran for 109 yards and a TD on 18 carries vs. Hou (9/27); added four catches for 40 yards … scored on a one-yard TD run in the third quarter vs. Phi (10/11), giving him a rushing TD in three consecutive games … ran for 101 yards and a TD on 20 attempts vs. Cle (10/18) marking his third 100-yard rushing performance in a span of four games; his three-yard TD run in the second quarter gave him a rushing TD in four consecutive games … had 82 rushing yards on 20 attempts and added 29 yards on three receptions @ Ten (10/25); marked fourth time in five-game span he surpassed 100 yards from scrimmage … missed two games (Weeks 12-13) on the Reserve/Covid-19 list … returned to action in Week 14 vs. Buf (12/13), but left the game due to a hamstring injury … inactive (hamstring) @ Cin (12/21) … made his postseason debut in the Wild Card matchup vs. Cle (1/10/21) and ran for 37 yards and a TD on 11 carries while adding five receptions for 30 yards; scored his first postseason TD on a one-yard run. 2019: Started all 10 games he appeared in rushing for 464 yards and four TDs on 116 carries (4.0 avg.) … also caught 34 passes for 251 yards and a career-high three receiving TDs … sidelined with a shoulder injury for five games and a thigh injury for one contest … ran 11 times for 33 yards, including a one-yard TD vs. Sea (9/15); added three receptions for 12 yards before leaving the game in the 4th quarter with a knee injury … set career highs in both receptions (8) and receiving yards (83) in a victory vs. Cin (9/30); added 42 rushing yards on 10 carries for a total of 125 yards from scrimmage; hauled in a 21-yard go-ahead TD reception … in a Week 6 victory @ LAC (10/13), rushed 16 times for 41 yards including a 12-yard TD run in the first quarter; also led the team with seven catches for 78 yards and a career-long 26-yard TD reception; marked his first career game with both a rushing and receiving TD … carried 23 times for 145 yards and a TD, adding three receptions for five yards vs. Mia (10/28); his 145 yards rushing is the second-highest single-game total of his career (146 yards on 10/28/18 vs. Cle); marked his first 100-yard rushing game of the season and sixth of his career; it was his fourth consecutive game with at least one TD; first game of the season with 150+ yards from scrimmage, the fifth-such outing of his career; earned his second career AFC Offensive Player of the Week honor for the performance … inactive in Weeks 9-10, 12-14 (shoulder) … rushed for 42 yards on eight carries and caught four passes for nine yards vs. Buf (12/15); hauled in an 11-yard go-ahead TD pass in the third quarter … carried six times for 32 yards @ NYJ (12/22), but left the game with a thigh injury … inactive (thigh) for the season finale @ Bal (12/29). 2018: Started 12 of 13 games played and was selected to his first career Pro Bowl after rushing for 973 yards and 12 TDs on 215 carries (4.5 avg.) while adding 55 catches for 497 yards and a TD … named AFC Offensive Player of the Month for October and AFC Offensive Player of the Week in Week 8 … missed three games due to an ankle injury … his 55 catches were the fourth most by a Steelers RB in a single season in team history … his 12 rushing TDs were the most by a Steeler in a single season since 2010 … became the first player in NFL history with four games within a single season of 100+ rushing yards, 50+ receiving yards and one TD … joined Franco Harris (1979) as the only players in team history with multiple rushing TDs in a game at least five times in a single season … became first player in Steelers history to score 10+ TDs in the first eight games of a season … became the second player in franchise history to reach 1,000 scrimmage yards in the first eight games of a season (Le'Veon Bell, 2014) … had a streak of four consecutive outings with 100+ rushing yards (Games 5-8) … made his first career start in the season opener @ Cle (9/9) totaling 135 rushing yards and two TDs on 31 carries while adding five receptions for 57 yards … his 135 rushing yards marked the first 100-rushing yard game of his career and the fourth-most in team history in a season-opener; his 192 scrimmage yards were the third-most by a Steelers player in Week 1 in team history; scored the first TD of his NFL career on a four-yard run in the second quarter and added his second TD on a 22-yard run in the third quarter … tallied 185 yards from scrimmage (110 rushing, 75 receiving), along with two rushing TDs in a win vs. Atl (10/7); amassed 99 yards from scrimmage in the first quarter, the most by a Steelers RB in the opening stanza dating back to 1991; gained 72 scrimmage yards on the team's opening drive, capping the series with a one-yard TD run ... totaled 129 yards from scrimmage (111 rushing, 18 receiving) and two rushing TDs @ Cin (10/14); became just the fourth different Pittsburgh player in team history to rush for 100+ yards and multiple TDs in back-to-back games, joining Jerome Bettis (1996), Barry Foster (1992) and Franco Harris (1979, 1976, 1975); marked first time in his career he ran for 100+ yards in consecutive games and also first time with multiple rushing TDs in back-to-back games … led all players in yards from scrimmage (212), rushing yards (146) and rushing TDs (2) vs. Cle (10/28), adding five catches for 66 yards; became the first player in Steelers history to rush for 100+ yards and multiple TDs in three consecutive games, and the first NFL player to accomplish the feat since Chris Johnson in 2009 … led all players with 163 yards from scrimmage (107 rushing, 56 receiving) and added his first career TD reception @ Bal (11/4); rushed for 107 yards on 24 carries and added seven receptions for 56 yards and a TD; his seven-yard TD catch from Ben Roethlisberger in the first quarter was his 10th TD of the year; eclipsed 1,000 yards from scrimmage (1,085) for the season … led the Steelers with 65 rushing yards on 13 carries and scored a two-yard TD run in the first quarter vs. Car (11/8); marked his 10th rushing TD of the year as he became the eighth player in Steelers history to have double-digit rushing TDs in a season; became the first Steelers player since Le'Veon Bell in 2014 to have at least one TD in five consecutive games … totaled 74 yards from scrimmage (60 rushing, 14 receiving) and scored two rushing TDs vs. LAC (12/2) before leaving the game with an ankle injury … inactive for Weeks 14-16 … returned to the lineup for the season finale vs. Cin (12/30) and 94 yards from scrimmage (64 rushing, 30 receiving). 2017: Played in 14 games and ran 32 times for 144 yards … also saw significant action on special teams … missed the final two games of the regular season and the Steelers postseason matchup with a shoulder injury … had at least one rushing attempt in 12 of 14 games played including nine games with multiple carries … made his NFL debut in the season opener @ Cle (9/10) and ran for 11 yards on four carries … had four carries for a season-high 26 yards in a victory @ Bal (10/1) … saw action vs. NE (12/17) but left the game in the fourth quarter with a knee injury … placed on injured reserve on 12/19. College: Played in 39 games in four seasons at Pitt (2013-16), and left ranked second in school history in rushing yards (3,733), total TDs (56) and rushing TDs (52), trailing only Tony Dorsett in all three … set ACC records for career rushing TDs and total TDs … returned to action in 2016 after enduring a season-ending knee injury in 2015, as he was later diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma … in 2016, named 1st-team All-ACC and earned the Disney Sports Spirit Award, the FWAA Courage Award, the Brian Piccolo Award and the Maxwell Club Thomas Brookshier Spirit Award … ran for 1,092 yards and 16 TDs and added 21 receptions for 302 yards and four TDs in 13 games … as a junior in 2015, played in one game and had 77 yards and two TDs on eight carries before suffering a knee injury … as a sophomore in 2014, set career highs for carries (298), rushing yards (1,765) and rushing TDs (26) in 13 games … his 26 rushing TDs, 26 total TDs and 156 points all set school single-season records while his 26 rushing TDs also represented an ACC record … named 1st-team All-ACC and earned ACC Player of the Year honors … also named a first-team All-American by the American Football Coaches Association becoming the first Pitt RB to garner first-team accolades in 27 years (Craig "Ironhead" Heyward in 1987) … as a freshman in 2013, ran for 799 yards and eight TDs on 146 carries in 12 games. Personal: Attended Erie McDowell (Erie, PA) High School where he played RB and saw action on defense … led the school to the quarterfinals of the PIAA Class AAAA playoffs his senior season after rushing for 1,680 yards and 21 TDs … as a senior, set a school single-season record with 164 points, including 26 TDs … also set school records for sacks in a season (12.0 as a senior) and in a career (17.0) … majored in Administration of Justice.
